headline: Here are the candidates running in Arizona's new 3rd Congressional District
author: Melissa Estrada
sentences: Gallego's campaign priorities, as listed on his campaign website, include: "building strong communities through education and social empowerment"; "defending immigrants, the LGBT community, and all other threatened communities"; and "advocating for jobs and economic opportunity."

Other issues listed include: providing promised "quality care and service" to veterans, maintaining U.S. energy independence by protecting the energy industry, enacting pro-growth tax policies to eliminate "punitive income tax," and supporting the Second Amendment.

Zink's campaign issues, as listed on his campaign website, are immigration, where he states his opposition of the "radical left's embrace of illegal immigration" and his support for securing the border and better enforcement of existing immigration laws.

Prior to serving in the House of Representatives, Gallego served in the Arizona Legislature; was vice chair of the Arizona Democratic Party; and was a delegate to the Democratic National Convention.

Democrats
Ruben Gallego
Ruben Gallego assumed office as Arizona's 7th Congressional District's congressman 2015, after serving in Arizona's House of Reps, D-27, from 2011-2014.
The 3rd district previously was known as Arizona's 7th Congressional District, before redistricting by the Arizona Independent Redistricting Commission.
Arizona's 3rd Congressional District covers Maricopa County, including parts of Phoenix, including South Phoenix, Laveen, Maryvale, and Glendale.
Zink spoke at a local "Justice for Jan. 6th" rally in honor of those imprisoned and injured during the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol riot.
With primary elections on Aug. 2, 2022, here are the major candidates running to represent Arizona's new 3rd Congressional District.
Zink was in attendance during the Jan. 6th event, but told The Arizona Republic that he did not enter the building.

Republicans
Jeff Zink
Jeff Zink is hoping to defeat Gallego and serve for the first time in public office.
Gallego is a Marine Corps combat veteran and has continued to focus on national security while in office.
He is the chair of the Armed Services subcommittee on Intelligence and Special Operations.
He sits on the House committees on Armed Services and on Veterans Affairs.
The redistricting map was officially adapted on Jan. 18, 2022.
Incumbents serve two-year terms and do not have term limits.
Rep. Ruben Gallego, D-Ariz., is running for re-election.
